Committee Praises Undergraduates—
Expect to Break Ground For New
Building in the Spring.

In an interview with Mr.George
L. Radcliffe, chairman of the
Dormitory Campaign Committee,•
great satisfaction with the result
of the drive among the undergraduates was expressed. The
amount given by the four collegiate classes is nearly $15,000. He
said that the spirit shown here
will be used as an argument with
the alumni for the campaign. Mr.
Radcliffe believes that the fund
will be raised in time to. break
ground for the new building next
spring. Although the amount subscribed so far is only $114,000, he
thinks with the returns of classes
not yet completely canvassed, and
subscriptions from a few men not
connected with the University, the
fund can be raised to the necessary $300,000.
Of the alumni classes, '00 lends
in donations with $10,960. The
class holding the runner-up position is '03; but since it has a subscription of $5,000 from a nonmember of the class, its position
is disputed by '92, who has raised
a larger sum from among its members, but whose total does not
equal that of '03, including the
$5,000 subscription from an outsider.
Swimming Team Has Good Practice.

FURNITURE OF QUALITY

FURNITURE

FUND FAR FROM COMPLETE

BALTIMORE

Although only 14 men were
present for, swimming practice
last Thursday night at the Baltimore Athletic Club, some very
fast swimming made up for the
lack in numbers. Under the direction of Coach Ortland and
Captain Hall, the candidates practiced starts and turns, and then
tried some competition at various
distances. The men were divided
into groups of three. The winners in the 100-yard dash were:
Buhrer, Johnston and Henry
Rowland. Davidge Rowland won
the 100-yard breast-stroke, while
Hall finished first in the 300
yards. Buhrer and Johnston, new
men on the squad, showed exceptionally good form and gave promise of soon developing into 'Varsity material.
The following men were present: Coach Ortland, Captain Hall,
Reins, D. Rowland, H. Rowland,
Buhrer, Powell, Parsons, Johnston, Call, Lord, Seitz, Kinnamon,
Marden and Assistant Manager
Miller.
Manager Gould announces that
all candidates will be notified
shortly of practice to take place
during the holidays.
Dartmouth started compulsory
athletics for freshmen this fall.
Golf, tennis, regular track work
and hiking are on the list of approved sports.

Although only 14 men were
present for, swimming practice

distances. The men were divided
into groups of three. The winners in the 100-yard dash were:
Buhrer, Johnston and Henry
Rowland. Davidge Rowland won
the 100-yard breast-stroke, while
Hall finished first in the 300
yards. Buhrer and Johnston, new
men on the squad, showed exceptionally good form and gave promise of soon developing into 'Varsity material.

Reins, D. Rowland, H. Rowland,
Buhrer, Powell, Parsons, Johnston, Call, Lord, Seitz, Kinnamon,
Marden and Assistant Manager
Miller.
Manager Gould announces that
all candidates will be notified
shortly of practice to take place
during the holidays.

athletics for freshmen this fall.

and hiking are on the list of approved sports.
